Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2009 10:02AM JacquelineG wrote: Hi there, I have some joint pains too. Lately I've felt it in my right hip and that's worried me (especially since next week is my 3-month and I'm concerned my onc will want to scan me) but today I walked for a while and it didn't bother me at all. These last 2 weeks I haven't exercised much because I had my exchange surgery, and those are the weeks I felt the pain -- so exercise does seem to help!) Everyminute, do you remember when you were allowed to run after your exchange surgery? I forgot to ask my PS and I'm getting very antsy after 2 1/2 weeks! Jackie
Posts.Title: Still pain, when will it go away... Mamita49 lexislove

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2010 05:40AM JacquelineG wrote: I hear you Helena! I go through my ups and downs, and just when I feel like I'm going through a bit of a rut and think of doing something about it, I have some good days and forget about it for a while (never completely forget though). But yes, this is a grieving process and like you, I had never been sick before and really dislike the hypochondriac that I've become. But I can see a light at the end of the tunnel for us - the more time goes by, the better we will feel for more extended periods of time. About the hip pain, I'm on Tamoxifen, but I do hear some people experience hip pain with it. I'm comforted by the fact the pain goes away for days and sometimes weeks at a time... And yes, all those pains are normal - the mastectomy severed all those little nerves around the breast area and some of them will slowly regenerate and cause twinges of pain - that's how my BS described it.  Very exciting that your reconstruction is coming up! Jackie

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2009 05:44AM JacquelineG wrote: I had a positive IM node as well. They found it during a PET scan after my mastectomy. They did not remove it surgically but I had a scan after chemo and it was GONE. I also had radiation of the IM nodes just for reinforcement. I had axillary nodes positive as well but I know of people that just had 1 IM node and no axillary nodes -- that is definitely a possibility! Try not to worry too much -- there are definitely options to treat this. My surgeon told me not to get too caught up in articles about IM nodes - most are outdated!

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2011 12:14PM JacquelineG wrote: I'm BRCA2 postive too! Yes, it's no fun to get the news... I was shocked, as I was the first in my family to get BC -- no breast or ovarian cancer in my family at all!! My parents were tested and my dad was the carrier. My sister is positive too. She had a prophylactic mastectomy last year and will have her ovaries removed once her 3rd child is born (she is pregnant now). I didn't find out I was positve until after my single mastectomy so I had the other side done one year later and ovaries removed at the same time.  The oophorectomy was a piece of cake (laparascopic).  Feel free to PM me if you have questions!! I know it's hard to swallow but once your shock is gone and you go through your surgeries, our prognosis should be no different than BRAC negative people -- that's what my oncologist has told me! take care,  Jackie

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2010 10:45AM JacquelineG wrote: Hi Kandy, I had a dry cough that developed about 2-3 months after radiation. I was concerned but my rads oncologist was pretty confident it was from rads. He said the radiation can affect the lining of the trachea temporarily (something about thinning out the lining that would usually trap particles, like the bronchi) and cause you to develop a cough. I'm happy to report my cough is now completely gone (i probably had it close to 6 months on and off). Try not to worry! jackie

Posts.Title: Two years ago.... KerryMac geewhiz

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2009 01:37AM JacquelineG wrote: I received 3 FEC and 3 Taxotere as well. I live in Atlanta, GA and have heard that FEC/T is being used more and more here in the U.S. as well. Side effects: FEC-- mainly nausea, general weakness, some night sweats (especially after the first round) and just an overall feeling of discomfort. The first round was the hardest, the following 2 not as bad. Oh, and I felt great after 1 week, so it was nice to have 2 good weeks before the next round... I took Emend and Zofran for nausea, which seemed to help a lot. Taxotere had very different SE's. More flu-like symptoms, joint and muscle pain (but only for about 10 days or so -- after that I felt fine). Although the first Taxotere was tough, it was nice not to have the nausea! I got some of those icky side effects like darkening of nails and watery eyes, but it really wasn't too bad. The last 2 Taxoteres were a lot easier to bear.  Chemo is no picnic, but I promise, it's worth it! My first PET scan after mastectomy revealed a positive mammary lymph node (aside from my 6 positve axillary nodes) so I was very freaked out knowing I still had cancer in my body. BUT I had another PET after chemo, and the lymph node completely cleared up -- no sign of cancer!! So every little discomfort was worth it!! You'll do great, Kerry! Jackie
Posts.Title: Starting FEC-T tomorrow.... KerryMac pip57

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2010 02:50PM JacquelineG wrote: My story is similar:  I had my 3rd child in 06, breastfed for a while (almost 15 months) and wasn't diagnosed until 08, Stage 3 by then. I was actually advised by my OB to get a baseline at 36 but then got pregnant, had a miscarriage, got pregnant again and then had my 3rd, so with breastfeeding, I didn't get the mammogram until I was 39. At the beginning I was very hard on myself for this, but now I'm trying to look forward. Thank goodness for all the Stage 3 ladies who are out 5, 6 7+ years and encourage us every day!

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2009 09:07PM JacquelineG wrote: Hi Clariceak,  I, too, had a positive internal mammary node, found on my PET scan after surgery. For me this was a BIG hurdle, and I couldn't seem to find anyone else with a similar diagnosis. But since then I've heard of others with positive chest nodes who are doing fine. They also told me it was inoperable but that they would blast it with chemo and rads. I had a PET scan after chemo and BEFORE rads, and guess what? no signs of that chest node! I was ecstatic, and hopefully radiation to the IM nodes was just a reinforcement... So just wanted to let you know chemo and rads are just as effective on those nodes as surgery, if not more!  You'll do fine! Jackie

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2009 08:38AM JacquelineG wrote: You read my mind, everyminute! YES, Thank You everybody. Hearing your success stories has helped me tremendously. Please keep them coming! Sometimes feeling positive comes naturally -- and I just wake up feeling strong. Other days I have to fight to stay positive. The recurrence fear monster just wants to grip me. And that is when I NEED to come to this place and see your Stage 3 NED stories! KerryMac, I went through the exact same chemo regimen you did (3xFEC,3xTaxotere). I was done with chemo on Dec. 12 and feel no effects of chemo anymore, haven't for a long time! You will get through this and feel FANTASTIC again! Everyminute, we were diagnosed 3 days apart and have gone through treatment pretty simultaneously. Your positive spirit and support of others going through this, even as you go through your own treatment, is inspiring! Thank you! Jackie
Posts.Title: Thank you to those who come back and give us hope! everyminute helena67

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2009 02:38PM JacquelineG wrote: Congrats everyminute, on your good appointment today, and also on going wigless! My hair is probably close to 1 inch around the sides but way too short and patchy at the top. I can't wait to go w/out the scarves though -- so sick of them! I stopped chemo Dec. 12. Might need at least one month til it's long enough to look decent. Keep running! I'm trying to do the same thing! Finally some motivation for me to exercise regularly
